comments: A broad introduction to the history of Jewish civilization from its Biblical beginnings to the Middle Ages, with the main focus on the formative period of classical rabbinic Judaism and on the symbiotic relationship between Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.    Students thoroughly enjoyed this course. As one explained, students learned how to “think critically” about ancient history. It provided a new perspective on the subject matter for many, and students appreciated this “secular insight into Judaism”.   Professor Dohrman received only praise. He was described as “excellent” and “dynamic” making class more stimulating. In addition, students celebrated his “clear lecture style”.     This course is recommended to both majors and non-majors alike. Even though the class is time consuming with a large final paper, a research paper, and lots of reading, students still didn’t seem deterred.
